description: Variant of knurled, from knurl. Surface analysis is gnarl +‎ -ed, though gnarl is a later back-formation. Popular use by 19th century.

adjectives.description: gnarled (comparative more gnarled, superlative most gnarled)

examples: Three chairs of the steamer type, all maimed, comprised the furniture of this roof-garden, with […] on one of the copings a row of four red clay flower-pots filled with sun-baked dust from which gnarled and rusty stalks thrust themselves up like withered elfin limbs.

entries.meaning: Made rough by age or hard work.
simple past tense and past participle of gnarl (Etymology 1)
simple past tense and past participle of gnarl (Etymology 2)
